ServiceWorkerContainer.summary: The ServiceWorkerContainer interface of the Service Worker API provides an object representing the service worker as an overall unit in the network ecosystem, including facilities to register, unregister and update service workers, and access the state of service workers and their registrations.

remarks.para: Most importantly, it exposes the method used to register service workers, and the property used to determine whether or not the current page is actively controlled.
ServiceWorkerContainer objects are exposed in the Window scope through and in workers using (if supported â€” check browser compatibility).

-Using Service Workers
-Service workers basic code example
-Using web workers

ServiceWorkerContainerController.summary: The controller read-only property of the interface represents the active {{domxref("ServiceWorker","service worker","","nocode")}} controlling the current page (associated with this ServiceWorkerContainer), or null if the page has no active or activating service worker.

remarks.para: This is the same object returned by .

ServiceWorkerContainerController.value: A object if its state is activating or activated, or null if there is no active worker.The property also returns null if the request is a force refresh (<kbd>Shift</kbd> + refresh)

ServiceWorkerContainerControllerchange.summary: The controllerchange event of the interface fires when the document's associated acquires a new worker.

ServiceWorkerContainerMessageerror.summary: The messageerror event is fired to the when an incoming message sent to the associated worker can't be deserialized.

remarks.para: This event is not cancelable and does not bubble.

-
-
-Using Service Workers
-Service workers basic code example
-Using Web Workers

ServiceWorkerContainerMessage.summary: The message event is used in a page controlled by a service worker to receive messages from the service worker.

remarks.para: This event is not cancelable and does not bubble.

-Using Service Workers
-Service workers basic code example
-Using web workers

ServiceWorkerContainerReady.summary: The ready read-only property of the interface provides a way of delaying code execution until a service worker is active.

remarks.para:
The property returns a {{jsxref("Promise")}} that will never reject, and which waits indefinitely until the associated with the current page has an worker.
Once that condition is met, it resolves with the .

ServiceWorkerContainerReady.value: A {{jsxref("Promise")}} that will never reject, and which may eventually resolve with a when there is an active service worker.

summary.blockquote:
WARNINGThe scriptURL parameter passed to this method represents the URL of an external script loaded into a service worker.
APIs like this are known as injection sinks, and are potentially a vector for cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.

remarks.para:
You can mitigate this risk by having a Content Security Policy (CSP) that restricts the locations from which scripts can be loaded, and by always assigning objects instead of strings and enforcing trusted types.
See Security considerations for more information.
The register() method of the interface creates or updates a for the given scope.

-ServiceWorkerRegistration: unregister() method
-Service worker API
-Using service workers
-Service-Worker-Allowed HTTP header

ServiceWorkerContainerRegister.returns: A {{jsxref("Promise")}} that resolves with a object.

ServiceWorkerContainerStartMessages.summary:
The startMessages() method of
the interface explicitly starts the flow of
messages being dispatched from a service worker to pages under its control (e.g., sent
via ). This can be used to react to sent messages
earlier, even before that page's content has finished loading.
